description: Very friendly service. Fresh Salsa Bar in Full Effect! Yum. Very affordable for the serving sizes and El Tesoro is bringin' sexy taquerias back to the TenderNob.
author: Braden B.

description: This is better Mexican food than some I've had in the Mission. I live for the chilequiles! The veggie burrito is huge, the veggie quesadilla is sooooooooooooo good. Everything is fresh and wonderful. My mouth is watering just thinking about it!
author: Heather G.

description: I really like this place. Everyone is so friendly, and they make my veggie burrito just the way i like it. Their chips are the best, too. My boyfriend loves their quesadilla's. It's enormous for such a cheap price.
author: Brenda F.

description: I love burritos with refried beans. I don't like burritos with salsa. Every time I go to El Tesoro I order my burrito with refried beans, no salsa. Every time I come home to eat my burrito, it has whole beans with salsa. I don't think it is a complicated request, which I make ever so politely. Maybe they think I'm an asshole because I put in a special request.
author: Wendy G.

description: This long, narrow corner taqueria has some of the best bean-and-cheese burritos on the planet. They're huge, salty, cheap, and perfectly symmetrical. Their hot (not habanero) salsa has a depth of smoky flavor you can neither get out of a bottle nor replicate in your home test kitchen. I'm not sure how they do it, but El Tesoro has mastered the extremely difficult art of making the simplest dish, very nearly perfectly, and giving it to you with a freaking smile. And that's how I judge "ethnic" food places - by the simplest dishes (or the most available, such as Pad Thai). As an added bonus, because the restaurant is in the Tenderloin, the people-watching is an exercise in sadism.
author: Angela O.

description:
I live across the street from here and go at least once a week. I love that you can order a dinner plate and EASILY split it between 2 pple. They give a lot of food. You get whatever meat  plus sour cream, guac and rice...

I lived in the mIssion and I know that Mexican food is supposed to be really good there, but this place is the same caliber. People love to love El Farolito and la Taqueria, but the food here is just as good. I'm going to say it's better. 
There isn't much of an atmosphere or anything. I don't recommend coming with a date to sit down here, or the like, but the food is good. Try the chicken fajitas. Had them last night and they were great
author: Roger W.

description: I'm surprised this place doesn't have higher ratings.  I've had the hardest time here finding a REALLY good burrito and then my boyfriend took me here.  It was awesome!  Probably the best carne asada burrito I've had in the city AND I was even sober eating it.  I think it was awesome... huge portions for the price and I LOVE how they grill it!  Amazing, and I'm begging my boyfriend to take me back here!
author: Rachel S.

description: This place is pretty tops compared to all the other Mexican places I've tried in the city.  They have great sit down style plates aside from the delicious tacos, which isn't always easy to find.  Their camarones el diablo is cooked in the perfect sauce.  The al pastor is just the right shade of orange and full of flavor, a total giveaway that they know what they're doing all around.  The salsas are all flavorful and plenty spicy when they claim to be and the horchata is good.  That warrants 4 stars.
author: Victoria G.

description: I am extremely picky when it comes to Taquerias. my favorites for the longest time were El Farolito on Mission and the one whose name escapes me on the corner of 16th & Valencia, after those two is Taqueria Cancun on Market, but this one has won my heart because not only is the food excellent and reasonable, the restaurant is always clean and the service is wonderfully friendly. it's right up the street from me and I'd definitely love to take my friends here!
author: Sakkara C.

description:
Worst Mexican food ever!!!

You want to make the kinda of Mexican food they make at El Tesoro. Get all your ingredients from Sysco. This is the Mexican food your lunch lady made.

The Adobada tasted like sloppy joes. The Tortas used rolls that reminded me of hot dog buns.

Seriously don't go here. DON'T EVER!!!
author: Dani Z.

description: This place really is a treasure! Probably the best taqueria I've found in San Francisco yet... Their super quesadilla is absolutely amazing! Service can be a little slow at times, but it's always worth the wait. I have to admit that once or twice I have felt *slightly* nauseas after eating here, but it wasn't bad enough to stop me from eating here or giving them less than 5 stars. Until I find a better tacqueria, El Tesoro gets 5 stars.
author: P A U L.

description: I wish I could give this place more stars I really want to but nearly every visit I've gotten some gnarly meat.  I will say that most everything has been good aside from this fact.  Don't get me wrong it didn't keep me from finishing my burritos or super tacos and I mean this kind of thing happens.  However it just happens too much for me here to continue to give it a better review.
author: Derek D.

description: This place is a real treasure in the tendernob!  The burritos are great, but the real standout for me is the quesadillas.  These aren't the appetizer chain restaurant style that are flat and dry, so get that out of your head immediately.  They're almost like a burrito that's been filled with cheese.  I've never had a quesadilla that was so thick and filling.  Also, the first few times I went here, I didn't know about the salsa bar, which is back behind the kitchen area, where there are also bathrooms and additional seating.  The service is very friendly, but if you're trying to give special instructions for your food, it sometimes helps to speak a little Spanish, because some of the clerks might have a bit of trouble understanding your English.  They also have a juicer machine with tasty fresh juice.
author: Joshua B.

description:
El Tesoro has some really good mexican food if you're looking for a quick and cheap bite to eat. The food is consistent and the staff is pretty friendly. 

There is another location on Geary a few blocks away. The Geary location is equally as good but the girl who works the register is a snotty b*tch and can't take an order without giving attitude and acting completely over her job unless you're also a spanish speaking mexican.

Overall both places have ok food and decent prices. The O'Farrell location has much more pleasant staff though.
author: g m.

description: It's been a few hours now since I've finished my burrito, and the debate has raged on between a four or five star review. It wasn't the perfect experience, had they offered a choice of tortillas, that would have sealed it. But for what they didn't have in tortillas, they more than made up for with the BBQ chicken. Not many places offer this, and as I watched them toss my chicken on the grill and pour BBQ sauce on top, I knew I was in for something good. Add in the no charge lettuce, a healthy portion of black beans and rice, and a grilled tortilla that holds it all together, it is pretty close to burrito heaven. I'll give it 4.75, which rounds up to 5.
author: Jason B.

description:
One of the best  taqerias I have ever tried. Great meat in whatever you decide goes around it. Burritos and tacos (though no hard shell) are both great  as well as their chips and range of salsas. 

As well as not being expensive and good service make this place one of my faves. Limited seating inside.
author: Brook B.

description: Burritos, quesedillas are hella good, a good price for it's size. One burrito is filling so is one quesedilla, and it's not like to stupid thin ones at taco bell, these are mad thick and big! I like their fish tacos, but i think the price is maybe a dollar more than what it should be for it's small size. I think it would taste way better if they fry batter the fish, so it'll have a crunch to it when you bit in to it!
author: kirehleen f.

description: stumbled into this taqueria a few weeks back whilst out boozing, place is not cheap like mission taqueria's,  but the carnitas burrito's and carne asada nacho's were quite delicious.  staff was friendly, but then again, we were drunk.  will return.
author: Pickle R.

description: I've had the shrimp burrito here on a couple of occasions.  Definitely one of the better burrito joints in the neighborhood, but I prefer several different spots in the Mission.
author: Luke P.

description: I wanted to like it, because I wanted there to be a good burrito possibility for lunch breaks. And maybe it was just a bad day, but the woman at the counter was pretty indifferent/borderline-grumpy to me. Then there's that whole thing about dictating your ingredients ahead of time. No pointing at what you want... you need to be able to think ahead about what makes a good burrito, and speak those words to her. So I started naming a few things that I wanted, and she told me that no, I could only put three items on or it would be a Super Burrito. But the items I was saying were cillantro, onions and hot sauce... I didn't want cheese or sour cream or anything else super-esque. So I stuck with whatever three items I had said, and ended up with a completely mediocre burrito made with clearly sub-par meat to boot. I would have given them bonus points if I could have sat in one of the front window-view tables, but there were toddlers (the counter woman's?) playing with crayons on them. Yeah -- I understand issues about childcare and I'm not going to knock anybody for having to bring their kids to work occasionally -- but this is the review of a restaurant customer, and as such, I was disappointed that I'd have to sit in the back room if I wanted to eat at the restaurant. I will say that the decor was above par for a tenderloin restaurant, and the place did seem quite clean. My burrito was made fast, and the guy doing the cooking was the one employee there who was willing to smile at me. So because of those points, I'm giving it two stars -- and I might even go back one more time to make sure I haven't misjudged them. But it won't be in the immediate future.
author: Zoe H.

description: i had a big old burrito.  it was pretty damn good... and cheap.  little heavy on the cheese, but forgivable.  the salsa bar was crucial.  the tortilla on my burrito was grilled and toasty and 100% pleasant.
author: Evan M.

description: Fabulous Mexican food at the edge of the Tenderloin.  Friendly and happy folks behind the counter.  Super Veggie Taco was a full meal for under $3.  Chips and salsa were fresh and tasty.  The BEST horchata (rice milk drink) north of the border...check this place out!
author: claudia t.

description: On the recomendation of some good friends, I had visited here before, and I thought the food was good.  Today, I went in and ordered carne asada tacos, to go.  I asked the woman at the counter, in Spanish, that I only wanted carne asada  with a little bit of onions...that's it.  She nodded, she wrote the order down,  I paid for my order, and I waited.  She gave me my order, I thanked her, again in Spanish and went on my way.  I got home, and unwrapped my tacos only to find that the tacos were full of cilantro, and that the carne asada tasted like pork.  Pork, uh no!    I know I betray my race by not liking most pork, but that's just me.  Also, whatever meat that was seemed drenched...uh, marinated in a highly seasoned sauce, possibly to mask it's flavor.  Diced flank steak (a.k.a. carne asada), corn tortillas, a bit of guacamole are simple pleasures for me.  It's kinda hard to make an error on such a simple order.  Oh! well, I'll go again, at some point.
author: Carlos C.
